description.en:
The course will enable students to understand what are the necessary knowledges, skills and attitudes to act as human rights educators. The course relies on the definition of human rights education as encompassing "education, training, awareness raising, information, practices and activities which aim - by equipping learners with knowledge, skills and understanding and developing their attitudes and behaviour - to empower learners to contribute to the building and defence of a universal culture of human rights in society, with a view to the promotion and protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms" (Council of Europe's Charter on Education for Democratic Citizenship and Human Rights Education, 2010). 

Students who complete this course will be able to apply the learning content within the practice module P2OG.02.216 and practice teaching human rights.

objectives.en: To provide a broad understanding of human rights education, its political development in the last decades, its pedagogical principles, the methodology for teaching human rights and to enable students to design educational activities and take action for human rights.

independent_work.et:
*	Independent work with study materials
*	Group work on designing an educational activity
*	Group work on designing an action plan
*	Writing a research paper
In the research paper, the student analyses critically a challenge to human rights education in the contemporary world. The selected problem should be registered via Moodle no later than 15 April 2017. The instructor may ask the student to choose another problem if the chosen problem is not suitable or too many students have already chosen the same problem. The paper should be submitted electronically as a Word-file no later than on 20 May 2017 at 12:00 (noon) in Moodle. For every started overdue day, the result will be decreased by four points, but papers which are late more than four days are not accepted and the student may not take the exam. The instructor cannot consider papers sent by email.
The paper must include title page, table of content, main body and list of used materials. For references, use footnotes. The length of main text (starting from the introduction and ending with the conclusion, excluding footnotes) should be 2000-2500 words. Shorter papers are not accepted or the result is lowered by the discretion of the instructor.
Independent identification of clear issues, the use of different sources and supportive materials are very important. All used sources must be referred to. In case of internet sources, the full address is necessary, not only the main domain (e.g. www.un.org). A paper based on copy-paste method leads to negative results for both the paper and the exam.

grade_preconditions.et:
*	Participation in all classes-seminars with no more than 3 missed classes permitted.
If a student did not participate in a class, he/she must submit, within a week, a one-page reflection paper on the text/problem discussed in the particular class. Each late submission of a summary decreases the final points by three points.
*	Timely submission and positive evaluation of a research paper.

grade_evaluation.et:
Criteria
*	depth of the analysis of problem(s) and reference to legal instruments/soft law
*	critical reflection on legal framework and countries' practices, norms, realities
*	structure of the text
Grades
A	the analysis of the problem(s) is detailed and innovative; the student makes reference to legal instruments for human rights education; the student knows the current developments of human rights in the country/geographical area referred to; the paper is thoughtful and creative; the form is excellent; overall, the text is a remarkable achievement [91-100 points]
B	the analysis of the problem(s) is very good with insignificant deficiencies; necessary references to the current state of human rights education support the conclusions; the form is very good; overall, the treatment of the subject is logical and smooth [81-90 points]
C	the analysis of the problem(s) is good with some deficiencies concerning specific issues; certain references to the current state of human rights education are made; the form is good; overall, the coverage of the subject is logical, but there are some weaknesses from the point of view of the whole [71-80 points]
D	the analysis of problem(s) is satisfactory with deficiencies is most aspects; just basic references to the current state of human rights education are made; the form is fair; overall, the treatment of the subject is plausible, but insecure [61-70 points]
E	the analysis of  the problem(s) is shallow with significant deficiencies is most aspects; only some rudimentary references to the current state of human rights education have been made; overall, the coverage of the subject suffers of superficial treatment, poor knowledge of law and unsound presentation [51-60 points]
Criteria
*	Convincing oral presentation
*	Articulated presentation, summarising major points of the research paper
